description: From Middle English light, liht, leoht, from Old English lēoht, from Proto-West Germanic *leuht, from Proto-Germanic *leuhtą, from Proto-Indo-European *lewktom, from the root *lewk- (“light”).

Cognate with Scots licht (“light”), West Frisian ljocht (“light”), Dutch licht (“light”), Low German licht (“light”), German Licht (“light”). Related also to Swedish ljus (“light”), Icelandic ljós (“light”), Latin lūx (“light”), Russian луч (luč, “beam of light”), Armenian լույս (luys, “light”), Ancient Greek λευκός (leukós, “white”), and Persian رُخش‎ (roxš).

entries.meaning: (physics, uncountable) Visible electromagnetic radiation. The human eye can typically detect radiation (light) in the wavelength range of about 400 to 750 nanometers. Nearby shorter and longer wavelength ranges, although not visible, are commonly called ultraviolet and infrared light.
examples: As you can see, this spacious dining-room gets a lot of light in the mornings.

entries.meaning: A source of illumination.
examples: Put that light out!

entries.meaning: (figurative) Spiritual or mental illumination; enlightenment, useful information.
examples: Can you throw any light on this problem?

entries.meaning: (in the plural, now rare) Facts; pieces of information; ideas, concepts.
A notable person within a specific field or discipline.
examples: Picasso was one of the leading lights of the cubist movement.

entries.meaning: (painting) The manner in which the light strikes a picture; that part of a picture which represents those objects upon which the light is supposed to fall; the more illuminated part of a landscape or other scene; opposed to shade.
A point of view, or aspect from which a concept, person or thing is regarded.
examples: I'm really seeing you in a different light today.
Magoon's governorship in Cuba was viewed in a negative light by many Cuban historians for years thereafter.

definitionGroups.group: A flame or something used to create fire.

entries.meaning: (slang) A cigarette lighter.
examples: Hey, buddy, you got a light?

entries.meaning: A firework made by filling a case with a substance which burns brilliantly with a white or coloured flame.
examples: a Bengal light

entries.meaning: A window in architecture, carriage design, or motor car design: either the opening itself or the window pane of glass that fills it, if any.
examples: This facade has eight south-facing lights.
Hyponyms: backlight, sidelight, transom

entries.meaning: The series of squares reserved for the answer to a crossword clue.
examples: The average length of a light on a 15×15 grid is 7 or 8.

entries.meaning: (informal) A cross-light in a double acrostic or triple acrostic.
Open view; a visible state or condition; public observation; publicity.
The power of perception by vision.
The brightness of the eye or eyes.
A traffic light, or, by extension, an intersection controlled by one or more that will face a traveler who is receiving instructions.
examples: To get to our house, turn right at the third light.

description: From Middle English lighten, lihten, from Old English līehtan (“to light, to shine”), from Proto-Germanic *liuhtijaną, from *leuhtą +‎ *-janą. Cognate with German leuchten (“to shine”).

verbs.description: light (third-person singular simple present lights, present participle lighting, simple past and past participle lit or lighted or (obsolete) light)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To start (a fire).
examples: Synonym: set
Antonyms: extinguish, put out, quench
We lit the fire to get some heat.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set fire to; to set burning.
examples: Synonyms: ignite, kindle, conflagrate
Antonyms: extinguish, put out, quench
She lit her last match.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To illuminate; to provide light for when it is dark.
examples: Synonyms: illuminate, light up
I used my torch to light the way home through the woods in the night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become ignited; to take fire.
examples: Synonyms: catch fire, ignite, conflagrate
This soggy match will not light.

entries.meaning: To attend or conduct with a light; to show the way to by means of a light.
examples: His bishops lead him forth, and light him on.

entries.meaning: (transitive, pinball) To make (a bonus) available to be collected by hitting a target, and thus light up the feature light corresponding to that bonus to indicate its availability.
examples: Light the extra ball by amassing 500 million points in the wizard mode.

description: From Middle English light, liht, leoht, from Old English lēoht (“luminous, bright, light, clear, resplendent, renowned, beautiful”), from Proto-Germanic *leuhtaz (“light”), from Proto-Indo-European *lewk- (“light”). Cognate with Saterland Frisian ljoacht (“light”), Dutch licht, German licht.

entries.meaning: Having light; bright; clear; not dark or obscure.
examples: The room is light when the Sun shines through the window.

entries.meaning: Pale or whitish in color; highly luminous and more or less deficient in chroma.
examples: She had light skin.

entries.meaning: (of coffee) Served with extra milk or cream.
examples: I like my coffee light.

description: From Old English lēoht, līht, from Proto-West Germanic *lį̄ht, from Proto-Germanic *linhtaz or *līhtaz, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁lengʷʰ- (“light”).
Cognate with Dutch licht, German leicht, Swedish lätt, Norwegian lett, Albanian lehtë, Latin levis, Russian лёгкий (ljóxkij), Lithuanian lengvas, Sanskrit लघु (laghu).

entries.meaning: Having little or relatively little actual weight; not cumbrous or unwieldy.
examples: a light load ; a lighter backpack after having removed the books ; light weapons

entries.meaning: Having little weight as compared with bulk; of little density or specific gravity.
examples: feathers and cork are light ; oil is lighter than water

entries.meaning: Of short or insufficient weight; weighing less than the legal, standard, or proper amount; clipped or diminished.
examples: to issue light coin

definitionGroups.group: Lacking that which burdens or makes heavy.

entries.meaning: Free from burden or impediment; unencumbered.
Lightly built; typically designed for speed or small loads.
examples: a light aircraft ; a light tank

entries.meaning: (military) Not heavily armed; armed with light weapons.
examples: light infantry; a troop of light horse

entries.meaning: (nautical, of a ship) Riding high because of no cargo; by extension, pertaining to a ship which is light.
examples: if a ship is light or partially loaded ; the light draft of a vessel, or its light displacement

entries.meaning: (rail transport, of a locomotive or consist of locomotives) Without any piece of equipment attached or attached only to a caboose.
examples: the light locomotives ; a locomotive may be moved light

entries.meaning: With low viscosity.
(cooking) Not heavy or soggy; spongy; well raised.
examples: a light bread ; sponge cake is a light cake

entries.meaning: Low in fat, calories, alcohol, salt, etc.
examples: This light beer still gets you drunk if you have enough of it.

entries.meaning: Slight, not forceful or intense; small in amount or intensity.
examples: a light drizzle; a light rain was falling; a light snow set in

entries.meaning: Gentle; having little force or momentum.
examples: This artist clearly had a light, flowing touch.

entries.meaning: Easy to endure or perform.
examples: light duties around the house

entries.meaning: Unimportant, trivial, having little value or significance.
examples: I made some light comment, and we moved on.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Unchaste, wanton.
Not encumbered; unembarrassed; clear of impediments; hence, active; nimble; swift.
(dated) Easily influenced by trifling considerations; unsteady; unsettled; volatile.
examples: a light, vain person; a light mind

entries.meaning: Indulging in, or inclined to, levity; lacking dignity or solemnity; frivolous; airy.
examples: Ogden Nash was a writer of light verse.

entries.meaning: Not quite sound or normal; somewhat impaired or deranged; dizzy; giddy.
Easily interrupted by stimulation.
examples: light sleep; light anesthesia

entries.meaning: Carrying little.
examples: I prefer to travel light.

entries.meaning: (curling) A stone that is not thrown hard enough.
See lights (“lungs”).
(Australia, uncountable) A low-alcohol lager.

verbs.description: light (third-person singular simple present lights, present participle lighting, simple past and past participle lighted)

entries.meaning: (nautical) To unload a ship, or to jettison material to make it lighter
To lighten; to ease of a burden; to take off.

description: From Middle English lighten, from Old English līhtan (“to relieve”), from Proto-West Germanic *lį̄htijan, from Proto-Germanic *linhtijaną, from *linhtaz (“light”).

verbs.description: light (third-person singular simple present lights, present participle lighting, simple past and past participle lit or lighted or (obsolete) light)

entries.meaning: To find by chance.
examples: I lit upon a rare book in a second-hand bookseller's.

entries.meaning: To stop upon (of eyes or a glance); to notice
(archaic) To alight; to land or come down.
examples: She fell out of the window but luckily lit on her feet.
